review_title: A fun student job and great experience!
job_title: Academic Support Technician in Eugene, OR
pros: It was a great experience, an overall calm office environment, and I enjoyed my coworkers. My supervisors were kind and supportive as well.
cons: The pay was low and only allowed about 15 hours a week. The hours can be a pro, however, if you need to put more hours into school than work.

job_title: Lead Instructional Specialist in Eugene, OR
pros: As part of academic and tutoring services, my direct supervisors are excellent when it comes to communicating about scheduling needs and time off requests so that workers have the support needed to provide holistic student support. Our department is very open to feedback, and in many cases, staff has ample opportunities to propose solutions to student barriers while working with faculty.
cons: Information surrounding pay and employment security based on funding feels nonexistent. There is also poor communication about the future direction and decisions surrounding student support, making it difficult to predict changes within the institution.

job_title: Chief of Staff in Eugene, OR
pros: -Wonderful dedicated community -Extremely brilliant colleagues and stakeholders
cons: None. Beautiful location. I learned a lot on the job.

job_title: Work Study Student in Eugene, OR
pros: My boss, Cindy Manning, was an amazing leader. Working there through Covid, she worked very hard to make accommodations for her work study students to minimize negative impacts.
cons: Understaffed. Hopefully they have moved in a different direction over the past couple of years.

review_title: Jobs are rewarding but the politics will make you cry
pros:
You will have the chance to make good, strong, powerful impacts in peoples lives
Takes a great deal of effort to get fired unless you get caught up in politics (usually just managers)
Good pay/benefits - note sense I left health insurance is not nearly as good like 1/2 as good
The cons are not nearly as bad as a four year university or private college so if you want to work in adult education and live in Lane County LCC is the best.
Outside of hiring LCC is a great place for people of diverse backgrounds to work and study. Ok that sounds bad but comparing to competition it really isn't.
I realize my review seems really bad but I'm just being overly honest. LCC really is the best gig in town.
cons:
Takes a great deal of effort to get fired, this includes sexual harassment and racism towards students.
LCC is a great school for learning tech skills including programming ect but is not only inept at it themselves but hostile to people that suggest using technology. This is changing for the better but slowly, in a couple decades may be everyone will know how use email. Though again this is how education is so yeah.
Hiring systems in generally are atrocious - this is one are where they are worse than their competitors, hopefully, I'm pretty sure anyway

job_title: Director, Facilities Management in Eugene, OR
pros: Highest paid Community College employee in the State of Oregon
cons: Always dealing with extreme budget cuts.

pros:
Good people as coworkers 
And nice campus
cons: Top heavy out of touch management

pros: Good benefits and support staff
cons: Term to term contracts and few full time faculty positions

job_title: Lead Academic Coach in Eugene, OR
pros: Many of the people who work in Academic and Tutoring Services are focused on student outcomes.
cons: There is no stability, we were all layed off at the beginning of the pandemic by mistake, and again many of us are finding our positions are tentative.

job_title: Early Outreach Specialist in Eugene, OR
pros: I really enjoy my coworkers and getting together for runs with my boss.
cons: The infrastructure of the school needs help, and the institution needs to be more student centered and less concerned with making the faculty happy.

pros: great students, academic freedom, flexible teaching schedule
cons: Classes assigned on seniority but not also merit

review_title: The right department head makes all the difference
pros: Great co-workers. Great opportunity to contribute to the betterment of the community through education.
cons: Position reassignments can move you from an amazing situation under a fantastic leader to an absolutely terrible situation, and there is little opportunity for lateral or upward movement to change that.

pros: Very friendly, comfortable from your home
cons: Most of the times you don't know what is coming.

pros: Feel like you're making a difference, I loved working with the students.
cons: A lot of drama, gossip and politics

job_title: Intructional Support Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: Good environment and nice employer
cons: Not many rooms for job advancement

pros: Time off, professional development opportunities
cons: Programs were often cut, resulting in layoffs

pros:
Small class size
Individual attention
Very student centered
Low cost
cons: requires transportation to campus site

review_title: Management needs to accept staff input
pros: The mission of the school is wonderful.  It provides education to a wide range of students and enables them to better themselves.  Staff is wonderful - they are helpful and supportive of each other.   Unionized so don't have to worry about being fired without cause and ensures good pay and benefits for full time workers.
cons: The college is at the mercy of public funding.  This has led to overburdened administrators and staff.  As a result, lots of projects are taken on without enough attention to outcome creating a lot of wasted resources.  Also, there's a lot of politics and good ol' boy or girl networks when it comes to rising in the ranks or even getting recognition.  Not enough attention paid to training staff - too many "feel-good" workshops.

pros: Quality benefit package. Ample paid leave. Some great people work here. Opportunities to help and mentor students be successful are available if have a role that allows you be available to assist them.
cons: Constant pressure to do more with less.  There are no consequences for those who don't perform and no incentives for those who do. The salary ceiling is very low and when you reach the top there are no internal opportunities for advancement.  Few professional growth opportunities and no time to utilize them. Campus is constantly inundated with political conflict between employees and board.  Leadership is ineffective and shows no sign of direction for change for the better.  Executive members use the role as launch pad to move to successful organizations after a short term.  The student experience is compromised by the lack of personnel and resources to sustain the infrastructure of services.  Employees are burned out and many feel trapped due to few opportunities in the local area.

pros: I've been at Lane since 1990. Began as part-time faculty, carefully kept below half-time to avoid benefits, but very much enjoyed teaching. Lost seniority when left over 5 years, so when budget cuts happened, lost teaching position. Have been classified ever since. Colleagues are wonderful. Ability to "self-manage" job and develop new ideas, though this culture is changing under recent management. Sense of equality in ability to participate in college governance.
cons:
Culture is changing. Fewer full-time staff/faculty means less commitment and ability to feel part of a connected educational "community". Students seem to be feeling this. Major change in decision making--less inclusive, more "top down". Staff who were accustomed to being asked to participate in new developments are now finding out decisions have been made without staff even knowing a change was being considered.
Very difficult to get through hiring process for full-time work, as it is very stilted and not set up to easily consider individual differences or follow up on perceived strengths in candidates if they don't specifically state them in answer to very scripted questions.

review_title: I worked in Specialized Support Services for 4 years w/o promotions/raises except the COLA. They were unethical, too.
job_title: Developmental Disabilities Specialist I in Eugene, OR
pros: If you can earn a position with PERS and a decent hourly rate it is an ok job. If you can get the union to help you or enforce the contract with LCC it is a great protection for workers. Make sure to rewd the union contract and undrstand PERS fully so you can maximize your benefits.
cons: It is hard to improve things because LCC always says "That is the way we have always done it," when you propose a new idea. They are also struggling financially, so much that there is a student organization asking for students to invest in LCC. They have been facing some difficcult financial situations because of their previous unethical behavior. It is important to ensure you are being compensated appropriately and are allowed to use all of your benefits.

review_title: Poor management, no budgets, dead end jobs.
job_title: Computer Support Technician in Eugene, OR
pros: Gives fair pay and benefits.
cons: Plans a lot for the future but never acts on the proper path to manage the college long term.  Poor management and terrible money/bugetary processes hamper the ability of the college to get out of a slump in student enrollment.  In the IT department there is no upwardly mobile path for any position and the loss of personel hampers getting any work done.  Too much departmental politics hampers day to day processes .

pros:
Was a good part-time gig as an instructor for a short while
Students are gratifying to work with for the most part 
Sometimes opportunities to teach online classes
Excellent support staff (office, tech, colleagues, )
Could get some health insurance for yourself if you worked for a term or two over a certain number of credits, which was a nice perk.
cons:
I taught part-time here for 6 years and it was extremely insecure/unstable work -- they hire oodles of part timers one term and then tell them to bug off the next, so it's only feasible if you have a steady full time gig in addition to this. You cannot live your life like that unless you are retired. 
I earned "seniority" in my department I was there so much for a few years,  but then when I had a premature baby, I was a away for two terms and they ripped seniority away, so I never got back into a class schedule there that worked for me. There was no protection for me. 
Teaching night classes feels like a potential safety problem as a female teacher -- I was often the only one walking across an empty dark campus and the only instructor inside a huge building. 
You cannot/will not be hired as a full time employee no matter what you do or how excellent your teaching, so don't take the gig thinking that's where it's going. 
The classrooms I taught in had negative technology -- this has probably changed since 2012, but I only had an overhead projector!

pros:
There are those amongst us that go up and beyond the call of duty to better the lives of the students are positions serve. 
Ample paid leave.
cons:
Cowardice, dysfunctional and apathetic management.  
Good-old-boy paradigm keeps those in the club protected and hooked up with perks such as attending conferences, retreats, choosing their desired work schedules and receiving quality technology. 
Not enough resources to effectively support students.  Constant political conflict amongst employees, labor unions and board makes for a toxic work environment. Little to No opportunities for advancement, higher pay or professional development.  Few are pulling the weight of many.  No enforcement of policies.

pros: Co-workers were generally good people.
cons: The college is  set up as a class system. Management is a protected category. Full-time and Part-time union staff is somewhat protected, with benefits. Time-sheet, part-time employees work 19 hours per week. In my department we would be fired if we worked over 19 hours per week. Time-sheet employees were somewhat represented by the union. No health care benefits besides access to the college health clinic. No paid vacation. No guaranteed hours. Disposable employees.

job_title: CIT Lab Tutor in Eugene, OR
pros:
I was able to use most of my time doing homework as the demands of being a lab tutor were pretty minimal.
I also learned from teaching so that was a plus.
cons:
Was only allowed to work something like 20 hours a week.
Sometimes having to help people with zero computer experience can be frustrating.
It took a long time for me to get the job without a lot of feedback about that.

job_title: Work Study Library Aid in Eugene, OR
pros: The job was really easy. The coworkers were mostly friendly. I never had to work to hard. The hours were really flexible.
cons: I did work study in the library. I loved working there, but it got really boring. It was also very dusty. I had fun chatting with coworkers until we were all reprimanded and no one was allowed to speak above a whisper.

review_title: Transforming lives through lifelong learning -- who wouldn't want to be part of that.
pros:
Stimulating and challenging work.
Professional development opportunities abound.
The ability to contribute daily to the success of brave students pursuing their dreams through higher education.
cons:
Budget limitations at the state level limit resources, while increased expectations, internal and external, stretch existing resources thin. 
Efficiencies not maximized during K-12 years leave many students underprepared when arriving at Lane, which in turn affects their ability to achieve success in higher education.

job_title: Consulting Practice Director in Eugene, OR
pros: Community college students are some of the most rewarding people to work with. Helping people make a transition and improve themselves is the core of what is done in that setting. Lane has a few places where this still happens solely by the might of a few spectacular individual contributors.
cons: Fights between the ruling administration and the heads of the unions have led to an organization incapable and unwilling to fulfill its mission to students. Spiraling debt is being piled on to students.

pros:
Laid back management.

Generally friendly people to work with.

Opportunity to be relatively independent.


Can be good for those starting out in a food-service role (those who I'd recommend these jobs to).
cons:
No room for advancement.

Most workers are part-time, even many of the long-time "good" workers.

Not likely to get full-time, and...

No Benefits (full-time).

Co-worker ethics and quality is a "mixed bag"; some work hard while others coast through at their expense.

Management often hesitant to remove "bad" workers.

pros: Working with students is great, the days go by quick as you stay fairly busy. Helping people feels good.
cons: As someone with 2 bachelors degrees and a masters in physics, it would be nice to make more than minimum wage. They also keep all employees under 40 hrs/wk to avoid giving benefits.

pros: For part-time work, they pay better and offer better advantages than many community colleges.
cons: It is, after all, still part-time work. Like many colleges part-timers outnumber full timers.  There is almost never a chance for your creativity to be recognized.

review_title: Great place to work when enrollment is up
pros: The benefits are good.  The hours can be flexible depending on your position.  There are great fellow employees.
cons: No promotions.  Union rules make it impossible to reward great employees.  Many positions stability are based off of seniority making employment during lower enrollment years unreliable.

review_title: Great place to work while going to school
pros: All the people I worked with were nice and supportive. My manager was understanding if I needed to adjust my hours some weeks in order to deal with appointments.
cons: Students sometimes want you to do their homework for them and get upset when you won't.

pros: Amazing sense of service and devotion in the employees
cons: Lots of burn out and very few folks that are here full time.  Moving up is tied to your degrees, not your abilities.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Springfield, OR
pros: Staff are very considerate, thoughtful, and accepting for anyone who needed assistance.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about this company.

job_title: Retail Sale Associate in Eugene, OR
pros: I really enjoyed working for Lane Community College. It was easy to to get along with my co-workers and the students are great.
cons: Not enough hours and student workers received more hours because they were Federal work study.

pros: Many opportunities for professional development, Fridays off in the summer, somewhat competitive wages, pleasant campus, full benefits for part-time employees
cons: Health insurance is getting more expensive and covering less, budget shortfall each year

job_title: Developmental Disabilities Specialist in Eugene, OR
pros: Working opportunities for community inclusion of developmental disabled adults that this department strives to accomplish.
cons: Part time hours with little inroads leading to full time challenges financial and professional development.

pros: My regular customers were great. Had fun doing the job
cons: Getting to school way early is a con. Anything else was my school schedule.

review_title: Truly committed to transforming lives through learning
pros:
Smart, talented faculty, staff and administrators
Open to new ideas and ways of approaching challenges
cons:
Chronic state underfunding
Animosity between union leadership and some administrators

review_title: Fantastic Place To Work and Go to School
pros: They really love the students and the community.
cons: Better pay would be nice...but it isn't bad and benefits are fantastic.

job_title: Academic Technology Specialist in Eugene, OR
pros: Tight knit community, available training, and great co-workers. Benefits and wages are nothing special but about what you'd expect.
cons: Limited funding and advancement opportunities.

job_title: Lead Banquet Server in Eugene, OR
pros: Very good people to work with, great atmosphere
cons: Hours are low sometimes bro

pros: great support while going back to school. Help with class cost
cons: Little to lack of communication when scheduling around classes.

review_title: It has its strengths and weaknesses
pros: Great mission, excellent benefits and great team of people
cons: Uncertainty about the future from both a financial and leadership perspective

pros: Flexibility, hours/days work well, encouraged to do school work as well.
cons: Cannot work more than 20 hours per week, weak hourly wage.

job_title: Interim Director Health Clinic in Eugene, OR
pros: Great employees. Love working with students
cons: poor hiring practices. terrible union/management relations

pros: Distance to travel from class is minimal.
cons: Pay could be better than it was.

pros: Work-life balance, benefits, currently all remote

job_title: Business Resource Center ­ Tutor in Eugene, OR
pros: Works with students schedule, on campus so no traveling
cons: Maximum of 15 hours per week as a tutor

pros:

pros: Great Place to work, Loved the staff!
